regretList.regret: In college I lived with my brother and his fiancé. I regret that when they were having relationship troubles I lied to him about one time when she had a new boyfriend over.
I regret getting married to my spouse. I didn't know the extent of my spouse's anxiety and the impact it would have on our lives.
Going to college and especailly taking on debt to do so. I've learned more out of college than in college, and nothing I learned applies to what I do today.
That I never learned to play a musical instrument.
I married someone NOT Jewish like me and did not stand up for raising my children in my faith. Now both my grown children are practicing christians.
This is a test. It's only a test.
That I did not keep myself physically active as I was raising my kids.  I took care of them and not me.
Ugly break-up of my partnership

I was too conservative in my job choices and stayed too long in one field. Not that I'm unhappy with my choice, but I wish I had had the courage to try (and fail) new types of jobs/careers when I was younger!
I regret not living in more than one (1) metropolitan area after graduating from college.
I was very shy and cautious as a child so I regret not taking more risks like riding the roller coaster or being more spontaneous in decisions.
I regret that I did not approach my initial college experience more seriously.
not helping my family more and then failing to finish my phd so it was a lose, lose situation.
I regret not seeking mental health care sooner.

I regret choosing too much fun and the easy way out in college instead of pressing end to execute with healthy habits and better results.

I regret not taking my physical fitness seriously when I was younger, to make healthy well being eisier now
I did not make a professional connection with a person who could have been instrumental in shaping my career. And the opportunity was... right there.
I let the fear of what other people would say stop me from being more outgoing in high school. I regret not taking more chances and being so shy.

On one crucial night, when I was 22, I turned down an invitation to a midnight movie on a work night.  I chose sensible (getting a full night's sleep for work the next day) over an adventure that might have altered/ accelerated my own coming out journey.  The sexy woman who asked me never made another such invitation; it was years before I could summon the courage to peek through that closet door again.
utufjh khvjgkk  kuyfku j
My biggest regret is not spending more time with my Mother & older Sister that have passed.
That I went through so much of my life unaware of impact of my choices and believing a negative narrative.
I regret that I worked so hard to “climb a corporate ladder” that led to nowhere. What a waste of time and energy I can never get back.

I started working on a graphic novel project years ago, but I was always busy with work and other responsibilities. Now I have metastatic cancer, and don’t know if I’ll be able to finish the project, or if I should even be using my time that way.
I treated my first girlfriend poorly. I never really connected with her on a personal level, just seeing her as a chance to have sex.
Letting my own fears hold me back from taking chances.

When I was younger and because of my insecurities, I chose a boy over a best friend. I lost that friend even after trying to make amends. It changed my whole social trajectory and taught me a valuable lesson about character.
I regret not learning more about my grandparents lives, and having deeper conversations about their history and younger days before they had passed.
not followed my instinct and intuition enough
Love Failure
I wish I had better defined goals when I was younger (e.g. career) and the confidence to pursue them. Instead, I look back and see many important decisions I made were merely reactions.
I don’t have any significant regrets.
Not spending more time talking to and getting to know other students when I was in college and law school.
I regret not baking my father enough baked goods.
test this thing.
Take more chances in leadership and travel more.

I did not insist on selling the business sooner. I was so busy and complained about it all the time. My husband said we needed the cash flow to stay in our house we built. After he died I refinanced the house and have had no trouble making the payment after selling the business.
Spent more time with my grandmother before she died.  I was ashamed to go back home after I gained a lot of weight.
I didn't take advantage of opportunities to travel while I was in college and before I had children.

I regret not taking my children more places for their betterment
and social enrichment.
Saying Yes to someone I did not love because I felt lonely.
I did not finish the doctoral program.
Not taking advantage of a summer volunteer opportunity in London the summer after I graduated.
My biggest regret is that I didn’t dig and push harder to get more details about my parents’ and grandparents’ lives and experiences.
Not recording my kids early days
I regret I didn't go to Uncle Bobby's funeral
Not learning how to play an instrument
not buying amazon stock earlier
I regret not pursuing a professional basketball career. I should have worked more on my post moves and made the league.
In 10th grade not explaining to a girlfriend what did/not happen
I regret not saving more money when younger.
Getting married and having kids.
I wish I had played volleyball in college. I was a student athlete and was recruited by several D3 schools, but chose to not play.
I regret that I did not spend more time with my husband alone  before he died.  He had so many family and friends that wanted to spend time with him.
Not buying more Amazon stock.  I wish I had made more time in my life for fun and friends instead of the pursuit of "more" - more money and advancements.
Saying and doing the wrong things when I really loved someone
Not getting an advanced degree before I had children.
I regret not taking more chances and pushing myself out of my comfort zone more in my 20s.
When I was in my 20s, I was careless with relationships and others feelings. I wish I had been more caring.
Hanging on to my resentment of my parents for many years

I do not like to think in terms of regret as I believe we make the best decisions we can at the time with what we know but I did cause myself hardship by thinking strength meant not asking for help when I really needed it. I've inadvertantly passed that on to my children and, as I'm learning that allowing people to see my vulnerabilities is necessary for emotional wellness, I have to allow my children to learn this in their own time.
Marrying someone I felt no passion for, then staying with him for 23 years.
I regret that I didn’t make more of an attempt to learn to speak French. I am a unilingual anglophone living in a bilingual province and that is my biggest regret.
Giving up on my university plans.  I bailed on myself and chose a much easier path.  I could have done much more and achieved far greater career success.
Staying with my wife for the kids... we are still together going through the motions. I am so lonely
I regret not getting to know my mother (and her heritage) better - about digging deeper in conversations, rather than just having the superficial conversations.

My biggest current regret is the idea that I'd really live and enjoy life...later. Once the next goal was met, the bank balance was at X, once the Line of Credit was at 0, once the timing was right. This delay in living, travelling and enjoying my life has cost me my 20s, 30s and some of my 40s.
Picking a different law school
Not doing better in school. Wishing i had better self possession during some trying times so i wouldn't have reacted as dramatically
Dating  way too young
Those times I couldn't find a positive in a tough situation. I made too many "surface" decisions.
Marrying then divorcing young
That I got sick and didn’t finish physiotherapy degree

I regret not having the confidence to believe in myself. I regret spending too much time waiting for the approval of others before i moved forward; relationships, finances, career. Although successful enough now, i have lived behind the 8-ball always. It come from another regret - not telling my parents to step up and support me emotionally and to accept my differences and love me regardless. They’re too old to have that conversations with now and one of them refuses to listen anyway.
I regret not seeing at the time how much I loved and was loved by my first love

I regret being scared to really ‘go for it’ in my 20s. I could have acheived so much in life, instead I was wrapped in a world of distractions - such as loser guys, and pretending I was dumb. It took me many years to ‘catch up’ with my career, my education and the development of my emotional intelligence.
Stealing a contact list at an event

When I was in upper elementary school, my friend and I auditioned for the school pop group. Naively, I think we assumed that both of us would be selected, or neither of us would be. Only 3-4 students were chosen to represent the hundreds on the school roll. I should have been thrilled when my name was announced, but my friend missed out, and, such was her influence and control, I felt compelled to decline. The music teacher contacted my parents and all three spent days imploring me to reconsider. I stubbornly refused. On the night of the performance, I regretted not being up on stage - the group appeared to be having so much fun. But the greater regret, the part that has stayed with me all my life, has been knowing that I didn’t take the chance that came my way because I succumbed to pressure from a person who felt no joy over my achievement; only bitterness as a result of her own disappointment. I’ve always been grateful for the lesson, but the choice I made remains a deep regret.
Listening to someone say I cannot dance and then giving it up.
- Not completing my PMP certification.
I wasn't "there" for my grandmother at the end of her life. I nursed petty grievances; I blew it.
I regret not having been a better, kinder, more patient parent.
Moving in with a boyfriend at the age of 19. I wish I would have experienced living on my own instead
Not being mindful of my young son’s turtle, Freddie, who died from neglect.
I regret I didn’t speak more with my mother when she was sick before she died.
Starting to smoke at the age of 19.
Embarrassing my husband in front of his mentors by being incredibly bossy and emasculating.
I wish I would have focused on both financial and physical health earlier.
I regret I did not leave my marriage of 31 years much sooner. It had been over four at least 15 years

I regret that I allowed a few negative/traumatic travel experiences from my much younger days prevent me from travelling most of my adult life. I just got back in touch with my inner adventurer and had one AMAZING trip to India before this damned virus got in the way of my plans!
Not taking learning seriously in high school.
Marrying my first husband.

Not continuing to work and get further education in the field in which I hold a Bachelor of Science, Microbiology.   Because of the relationship I was in at the time I graduated, I chose to forego additional education in my field to maintain and further that relationship.   That relationship ended in divorce.  I regret not choosing myself and my education first.

I regret being in such a hurry to rush through college and into adulthood. While I don't regret marrying my husband, I wish somehow we had met later in life so I could have had more experiences before launching into my career - travel, volunteer work, widening my horizons.
I regret making a dismissive statement to my father.
Not seizing the opportunities I had to become a professional singer

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: I regret not performing better at my interview for the University of Cambridge, UK. I had prepared well, and had good predicted grades and references from my school, but the interview could have been better, and I didn't get an offer.

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: Never playing more cricket.  Never doing an electrical qualification.

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: Taking a job that I knew wasnt right first me, still there 25 years later, never enjoyed a day

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: Not understanding the risk that my late wife’s breast cancer caused, and not ignoring the genetic counsellor who said we could wait before a mastectomy. A mastectomy that may have saved her life.

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: Not being braver

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: Not standing up for myself in the face of parental abuse (mental, physical and emotional)

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: Didn’t spend more time to learn and study when I was younger

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: Not telling Adam Anderson that I still loved him and couldn’t imagine my life without him. I was barely putting my life without him together when he came back, asking for another chance to try again. I should have said, I love you, yes let’s try again. It’s been 18 years and my biggest regret.
I regret marrying young and for the wrong reasons. We have been married for 19 years, but my spouse would’ve been happier with someone else.
Never trying to playing a sport in high school and never trying out for my college marching band. Both experiences that would have enriched my life but I didn't even try - that's the real issue.
Marrying my ex-husband. I knew I was Making a mistake in my wedding day, but it felt too late to call it off. Then I got pregnant on my honeymoon.
Not going to college right out of high school (when my parents were willing to pay for it) may be my biggest regret.
Not spending more time with my grandmother and mother, just telling them how much I loved them
Not learning a foreign language is something that I regret although I'm told I can remedy it.
Not becoming a national magazine writer earlier in career. Not taking chances
I regret getting married at 19 years old.
I regret having greed take over my honesty. While it didn’t hurt anyone, it hurt my integrity that’ll last for life.
I should have faced my fears earlier in life.
I don’t think I have any regrets.

Having serious relationships too early in life (my first serious relationship was at 18, second one at 19, and the third and last—I married him— was at 21). I didn’t enjoy or take advantage of my college experience in part because I was preoccupied with my boyfriends rather than on growing as a person and woman.  This is my biggest regret.
That in 1964, I gave my daughter up for adoption. And that I didnt start a movement to end the social stigma of not having a husband to assure a child's legitimacy.

I regret not taking the time to discover my individuality before my first marriage.  I believe that it played a role in how I handled the relationship with my ex, as well as how my sense of dissatisfaction led me to be less patient with my kids.  I tended to be the disciplinarian in the marriage (not in a physical sense) by being firm in expectations.  My kids are in their mid-20s now.  Sometimes I feel like that created a distance issue.
Not stayed in NY with my ex
I regret not maximizing my oportunities instead of just doing the average (i.e. not studying really really hard at College).
Not taking the time to let people know how much I loved them before they passed away.

My youngest son died at 3 years old and we donated his organs... before he was taken to the operating room we had a ceremony at the hospital with family and friends and after that we left. I regret not having walked by his body to the limits of the operating room. I was still in a certain amount of shock so I am not angry at myself but if I could go back I would walk with him...
I regret studying in science because people told me I was good at it and that it was a good job instead of studying in communication or psychology.

I went to New Zealand for an MBA for two years. I was offered a job and decided to stay for an extra year or two.  I loved the lifestyle and it seems a place where creative people who do not in other countries can find a place.  But...I decided to move to Australian and then back to Canada.  My regret? It took a while to figure the out but leaving NZ is my biggest regret.  While Canada is home, it does not feel like home.  I feel lije a foreigner here now. I have skills, expertise and a way of thinking that is not that welcome here.
Micromanaging an experience with my son when he was in 5th grade.
I regret not serving in the military, but it’s not a large regret.
Majoring in Psychology instead of Math. Following the foolish advice to do what you love instead of what your good at.

I regret not traveling abroad more during college/mid 20’s.  As a student athlete my schedule didn’t allow for it and when I started working I didn’t feel I had enough cash in the bank to splurge.  Now, in my mid-30s, with kids in the future and a rampant pandemic, I’m afraid I won’t ever be able to make the time or even have a chance to do so.
Not being able to save my elderly mother from my abusive sibling.

I don’t think it’s regrettable?  I got pregnant, and then married. My husband.  I love my family- but have wondered how life would be different with a different partner. I am also grateful for this decision too.
Staying in a marriage
I didn’t vote for my sibling for high school class president because no other hands were raised for her (they should have had a ballot).  As it was high school, it was more of a popularity contest.
Too early marriage.

to cheat on my husband
not being conscious in my ealry career
I regret a little of Things in my life, for example when I was not assertive and brave enough in my former workplace.

I lived a life for over 15 years which wasn't mine. Now at the age of 37 I started to create my own life, the rality of my life which roots from me. Maybe it's the pandemic that gave time and chance for this dicovery, to turn things around, or maybe it would have come to this point anyway. One thing is sure. Nothing will be the same anymore, and the change will be for the better. I believe it is for the better.
Wasting time
I regret not leaving a bad marriage sooner.
Unhealthy college relationship.
I was not as attentive to my son as he was growing up.
I regret not finishing college.
I should have taken more risks in my earlier careers when i was freelanceing and worked with film
When I was 15 I was too scared to go after the girl I had a crush on. That same fear stuck with me for too long and set me back, even though I later overcame it.
Divorcing too late...

That I didn’t work as hard as I could when in school. I am happy with my work and life today but I think that having the right grades would have opened many more doors sooner as I would have been able to study exactly what I wanted from a start.
That I didn’t say ”no” to taking on responsibilities and let it affect my health.
I regret leaving a job too early and not visiting an aunt who was dying - I didn’t believe (didn’t want to believe) she was dying.
I regret that I didn't keep up my yoga practice that I started decades ago.

Not going to law school 
Not finishing my PhD
I wish I had considered the cost of private college, student loans, and the small bubble of monochrome people I was surrounding myself with when I chose my undergrad program.
I regret not going away to university. I think my life would be drastically different if I had.
I regret to say hurtful things to my parents and friends.
Not taking more chances and risks

I regret not going to a college that was recommended to me by my wonderful librarian in high school. The school was an arts focused, work to earn your tuition college in Kentucky. Instead I chose the same college as all my friends at the time. I will always wonder how my life would’ve been different. He was right.
I regret how I handled the planning and execution of my wedding because I wa ask angry my sister was pregnant and due the same week.
Not moving to a different location from where I grew up.
Not speaking up sooner. Not suggesting solutions as often as I complained about something. Not recording and exposing more.
Behaving in a restaurant in a way I saw someone in a movie do it. What an asshat I was.
Not having a better relationship with my husband while our kids still lived at home. Could have been a better role model.

In pondering, I don't truly regret anything. There are events that perhaps I could have done differently, but that also would substantially change who I am today, who I'm with, and even where I'm living, all of which I love. I have learned from those events to adjust my future rather than dwelling on "what might have been."
If anything, I would say I regret not forming more disciplined habits in my youth.

I moved for a teaching job that was great for my career but my son ended up in a really bad school where a teacher was fired for bullying him.  Wish I could have known and avoided his educational experience including that.
Not changing companies several years ago. I have been at the same company for 27 years now and although they are good to me it would have been beneficial to get other perspectives.
Not talking more with my parents about their lives.
Not having a better understanding of money early in life. Also, not understanding the impact of the college you attend or the value of high stakes tests.

I regret never living alone. I went from my parents home to a home I shared with my husband. I bought the house when I was single, but then we got engaged and I decided to wait to move in until we got married.
Spent more time with, and done more for, relatives who have died

I regred giving up too easily, as a freshman in college taking Computer Science classes. I changed majors (and schools) and graduated with a history degree, only to teach myself how to code later and now have a carrer as a software developer. Granted I matured a lot, and a lot of infrastructure, languages, tools and frameworks matured too, but if I hung in there, I'd be in a better position financially and would have had more opportunities than now. Hopefully I can catch up. Cheers
I stayed in jobs where I was not valued for too long.

I regret not doing a semester or a year abroad when I was in college.  I wish I had the language fluency, life experiences, and memories that truly *living* abroad would have given me.  I'm 51 years old now - and I still hope to remedy this regret before my time on this planet is up.  Actually, "hope" is not a sufficiently intentional word.  I *plan* to remedy this regret before my time on this planet is up.  Looking at my answer staring back at me from my computer screen right now, I also realize that - although I still feel reasonably young at 51 - I'm not guaranteed unlimited time to fix this.  I need to get on this sooner rather than later.  [Scrambles off to begin planning...]
Not spending time with my grandparents when I could before they died
Not knowing my son's mother better.
Not doing a graduate degree
I regret not following my dream
Regret that I put off doing things until "the right time".

Spending more quality time with my family and friends. I spent time with them but the quality could always be better and that’s something I hold myself accountable for. I could have hugged a little tighter and made effort to listen a little better.
Getting married without listening to my gut (and my parents). Resulting in divorce within a year after discovering my spouses hidden drug addiction.
I regret taking the safe path rather than pursuing a career that would have been more risky but also more fulfilling.

I regret for not taking school serious, study more and read more while I have the leisure time. I’m at my 30’s, still not too late but it would’ve been a head start if I were to be more responsible in my early life. 

I regret for not making good friends and maintaining the friendship that I could cherish today.
I regret not paying off my debts when I had the money.
Spend more time of quality, enjoying the moment with my family, people who I care, friends and of course, family members and pets (dogs) that have passed away.
Not making relationship decisions easier, wasting time with struggling
I regret not saving money early in my working life.
unfaithfulness
Actually I dont like to regret and I believe that everything is happened in my life for my best future.

I regret not prioritizing family. I believed the doctor’s opinion on a fertility issue and after 4 miscarriages, we stopped trying. I wonder what our life would be like if we had ever had children together.
Not pushing myself beyond my expectations or assumptions of old myself. I felt that there are tons of opportunities
I have impulsively made choices towards gratification rather than staying the course. Life has been interesting but uncertain.
Not looking after my health through the years. I did lots to hurt my health and not much to help it. Also, I did not save for my retirement and now I'm 62 unhealthy and broke.
The way I treated relationships as a teenager
Letting other people tell me what I want.
How I have treated others, when I wasn’t living up to my own standards.
I regret not studying abroad in college.
Not being more present and involved with my children and their hobbies/interests when they were younger. I mean, I was involved, but I could have been more involved.
Built a house
not being 'adult' earlier
I made a shit ton of excuses to lie to myself about my lack of affection for someone while I really have feelings for that person
my life is a story of regrets
Obeing my society unnecessary restricting rules during my teen years ,expressing myself confidently (physically and mentally) , and caring what people thinks about me
Wish i did’t leave my country when i was young. Have lived in three different countries and feel homeless.

Biggest regret ever: leaving my one true love 25 years ago, because I was too young back then to have the courage to stay in a foreign country without an education or job and not skilled enough in the local language to obtain either within a reasonable time period. Went back to my home country and got a great education and an even more fantastic job, but have not been able to find the right match thus leading to trying out the concept: if you cannot get the one you love, try to love the one you can get (which is a poor choice!)

That I decided to marry a woman I have been struggling to live with for almost seven years now just to please my aging parents who thought it would do them an honour to see me married before their retirement age. It feels like my real wife is also married somewhere else as I had to push her away for the woman I live with now...total regret that one
I regret not listening to my instincts earlier because it would save me from severe depression due to an abusive relationship.
I got married too soon after I met my husband. I should have taken more time for myself and be more brave to stand up my parents.
To get married too early
I had put too much pressure on my wife when we moved abroad for my new job. I should have quitted and went back home to my old job.

Being truer to myself earlier. Not trying to just fit in and do what I “should” be doing. I wish I had figured that part earlier. I made a lot of smaller mistakes that turned into regrets because I wasn’t true to myself.
Keeping on a relationship
I seriously regret not learning more about the power of money, and the how to manage it better.
Not doing things - travel -  because i thought i had to establish a career first
I wish I'd had a deeper, closer relationship with my father.
listened more and be more confident in myself.

I regret breaking off the contact to a friend I had a crush on ten years ago. At that time I thought I couldn’t handle the pain of a broken heart. Nowadays I regret my decisions because I’ve learned that crushes and heartaches go away and that friendships could last through those feelings.

Not spending more time with my grandmother, since I was studying in Germany and, everytime I flew back to Spain, I ended up spending more time with my friends and my girlfriend (at the time). I wished I had spent more quality time with her.
I regret marrying a man who turned out to be abusive/violent and having kids with him.
Lost the chance of doing what I love because I listen to my parent's advice to study, get PhD and have an ordinary life

I have a few- one is not telling someone that I had very strong feelings about that I loved them. I think it I had it might have changed the relationship that we had and maybe had a different outcome but I was afraid. 

The other regret I have is not exploring more options for college. I had a full ride opportunity and then decided against attending the college (sometimes I regret that too with my high amount of student loan debt.) While I ended up loving where I went to college, I always wonder what other experiences I might have had somewhere else instead of the safe option I chose. 

My final is just not living life. I've always felt like I needed to be safe and so didn't do somethings that now I wish I would have. 

I think regret is a lot of "what ifs" in life. I always wonder how things might have looked different if I had chosen something else.
